newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine lower house passes anti-tax evasion bill.
newsitem.headline: Argentine lower house passes anti-tax evasion bill.

text.p: Argentina's lower house of Congress approved and passed to the Senate late Wednesday a law to allow the tax office to close businesses and fine shoppers who fail to show receipts for their transactions.

The law, actively sought by new tax chief Carlos Silvani to crackdown on evasion, will allow inspectors to shut a business for three days the first time it is caught failing to provide a receipt for a sale.
The second time, firms will be closed for 10 to 20 days and, the third time, for up to a month.
Shoppers will be fined the first time 10 to 20 percent of the cost of the merchandise they bought. The second time, the fine will be of 20 to 30 percent and the third time 30 to 40 percent.

"Tax collection should be $35 billion (a year) and it only reaches $19 billion. Failing to hand out receipts is one of the biggest problems," Leonel Assad, advisor to Silvani, told local radio Thursday.
Penalties are for transactions valued at more than $10. The law also provides for $500 to $20,000 fines for businesses which fail to keep all documentation on its transactions.
The bill was passed to the Senate where it will have to be approved before it is signed into law.
